> 
> A quick and minor question: out of curiosity, how does this techniqu=
e behave
> if the population as a whole has stagnated for more than 50 gene=
rations
> (which is very common at the end of long runs).
> 
> -jeff
> 

Of=
 course the response to population-level stagnation can vary from one versi=
on of NEAT to another, but in my own version of NEAT (and I think in JNEAT =
as well), if it goes some number of generations beyond the dropoff_age with=
 the whole population stagnating, then it kills off all the species except =
for the top two and then divides the entire next generation between them.  =
This procedure is a form of "delta coding," which is a name given to simila=
r approaches to stagnation from before NEAT.  For example, I believe Fausti=
no Gomez's ESP algorithm does something similar.  The idea is to "zoom in" =
on the most promising areas of the search space and basically double down o=
ur bets that something good is there.  Of course, there is a downside to th=
is idea, which is that it strips diversity out of the population and furthe=
r invests in something that has not been working so far, but on the other h=
and, it's not like anything has been going well anyway, so a gamble isn't t=
hat bad at that point.  

It would also be perfectly reasonable to do somet=
hing else, or not do anything at all, as alternatives.

ken
